snippet: Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner, suggested that the Council was notably at a loss to offer ideas — any ideas at all — for how to stop violence among young minority men.
abstract: New York City Police Commissioner Raymond W Kelly defends controversial stop-and-frisk tactics, one of his signature policing strategies, to City Council members at hearings; Kelly makes an unusually expansive and rare attack on the council itself, which he suggests has offered no viable ideas for solving growing violence among young minority men.
lead_paragraph: Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner, suggested that the Council was notably at a loss to offer ideas — any ideas at all — for how to stop violence among young minority men.

headline.seo: Kelly, Head of N.Y.P.D., Fights Back at Council Hearing
headline.main: At City Council Hearing, Police Commissioner Fights Back
headline.print_headline: At Council Hearing, Kelly Fights Back on Stop-and-Frisk Tactics
